definition: benefit from others' dispute (idiom)
surname Zuo
to sit/to take a seat/to take (a bus, airplane etc)/to bear fruit/variant of 座[zuo4]
to receive/to accept/to collect/to put away/to restrain/to stop/in care of (used on address line after name)
fisherman/to fish
surname Li
sharp/favorable/advantage/benefit/profit/interest/to do good to/to benefit

sentences.english: Get the south and north side gangs to kill each other so someone else can take over.
sentences.chinese: 让南北两边的人杀个两败俱伤然后某个人坐收渔利。

sentences.english: You can hunker down and take it.
sentences.chinese: 你完全可以继续跟进，坐收渔利。

sentences.english: Hence, strategically, India can let US/Japan to confront China in SCS.
sentences.chinese: 因此，战略上，让美日对抗中国印度坐收渔利。

definition: sit on the mountain and watch the tigers fight/watch in safety whilst others fight then reap the rewards when both sides are exhausted (idiom)
two tigers fighting (idiom); fierce contest between evenly matched adversaries
lit. sandpiper and clam war together and the fisherman catches both (idiom); fig. neighbors who can't agree lose out to a third party
pinyin: yu4 bang4 xiang1 zheng1 , yu2 weng1 de2 li4

definition: lit. sandpiper and clam war together (and the fisherman catches both) (idiom); fig. neighbors who can't agree lose out to a third party
both sides suffer (idiom)/neither side wins
to watch the fires burning across the river/to delay entering the fray until all others have been exhausted by fighting amongst themselves (idiom)
to loot a burning house/to profit from sb's misfortune (idiom)
see 窩裡鬥|窝里斗[wo1 li5 dou4]
to take advantage of sb's misfortune/to loot
two tigers fight (idiom); fig. a dispute between two powerful adversaries/a battle of the giants
to fish in troubled water (idiom); to take advantage of a crisis for personal gain
to reap where one has not sown (idiom)
if two tigers fight, one will get injured (idiom)/if you start a war, someone is bound to get hurt
pinyin: liang3 hu3 xiang1 zheng1 , bi4 you3 yi1 shang1

definition: to lend sb a knife to kill sb/to get sb else to do one's dirty work/to attack using the strength of another (idiom)
internal strife (family, group, etc)
